repnme.cdata!:
Promoting an inclusive, equitable and
            efficient social protection system in Colombia

abstracts.cdata!:
This Result Profile talks about
            promoting an inclusive, equitable and efficient social
            protection system in Colombia. There were several challenges
            that remained in Colombia, especially in terms of the
            limited coverage of the pension and health systems, and
            unemployment insurance, which were available mostly to
            formal workers. Similarly, programs aimed at fostering
            employability, such as training, labor intermediation, and
            other employment services, were not reaching the lower
            segments of the population. A critical challenge was to
            enhance the coordination between these programs.
            International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD)
            supported Colombia in the implementation of the reforms. In
            parallel to this operation, the Bank also provided
            complementary technical assistance in the form of seminars,
            policy notes, short technical briefs, as well as direct
            comments and suggestions for the technical aspects of some
            of the regulation and policy design in social protection
            areas. Improvements in social sector management benefited
            all citizens through more efficient and transparent central
            administration, through better access to public service
            delivery, and through better quality and access to public information.

repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - Development Policy Loan (DPL) on
            Promoting an Inclusive, Equitable and Efficient Social
            Protection System Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Development Policy Loan
            (DPL) on Promoting an Inclusive, Equitable and Efficient
            Social Protection System Project for Colombia were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory; the risk to development
            outcome was moderate; the Bank's performance was
            satisfactory; and the Borrower's performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: an effective
            operation is supported by strong analytics. A long tradition
            of technical assistance, analysis and impact evaluations in
            the context of ongoing Knowledge Services, policy or
            investment operations was critical in the identification of
            key reforms and in the design of specific elements of such
            reforms. A long-term engagement facilitates the
            implementation. This DPL built on a long series of financial
            and technical services provided to Colombia in the area of
            social protection over the past decade. A focused approach
            serves to minimize Government transition risks. A single
            tranche DPL in the midst of a Government transition always
            pose challenges in the operational design. Reform is a
            continuous process. Both the Government and the Bank team
            were quite conscious that reform is a slow process and that
            long term engagement yields more profound results than any
            single operation could. A multi-sectoral operation is
            manageable if the teams are selective in choosing a few key
            strategies. While the operation covered many policy areas,
            it only supported a few key actions within each of them.
            Still, the fact that these policy areas were at different
            stages of advance posed challenges of selecting appropriate
            indicators to monitor. Strong coordination on the
            Government's side is necessary when many ministries are involved.

repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - Development Policy Loan (DPL) on
            Promoting an Inclusive, Equitable and Efficient Social
            Protection System Program

abstracts.cdata!:
The Colombian economy is facing the
            impacts of a sharp aggregate demand contraction, but sound
            macroeconomic policies implemented in recent years have
            substantially improved the country's economic
            resilience against crisis. In the near term, economic
            activity is likely to reverse its decline and the
            Bank's base scenario for Colombia includes gross
            domestic product (GDP) growth of 0.4 percent in 2009 and a
            modest rebound of economic activity in 2010. Despite the
            impact of global conditions, Colombia is in a better
            position to confront the global crisis than other Latin
            America and Caribbean (LAC) countries, as a result of its
            countercyclical monetary policy and fiscal stimulus over
            2009. While there remains uncertainty as regards to the
            depth and length of the global recession, neither external
            nor fiscal sustainability appear at risk. The operation
            proposes to consolidate past gains and support the reform
            agenda in areas that need strengthening and consolidation.
            The development objective of the operation is to strengthen
            an inclusive, equitable and efficient social protection
            system by: (1) promoting greater integration, efficiency and
            equity of social insurance, (2) improving the targeting,
            efficiency, and articulation of social assistance programs,
            and (3) promoting higher quality training and employment
            services. To achieve this objective, the operation supports
            policies in a broad range of areas, in particular: 1)
            efforts to increase the coverage of inclusive systems
            serving the entire population such as the national training
            and labor intermediation system or health insurance; 2)
            efforts to build an equitable system that serves the poor
            and vulnerable through improved targeting and coordination
            of social assistance and greater efforts to reach the
            poorest; 3) and efforts to increase the efficiency of social
            protection through improved information systems,
            rationalization, simplification of processes, and
            improvements in program design.
